**Ring mail** is a type of [body armor](/wiki/Body_armor "Body armor") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.2 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.3 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

[Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") start each game with +1 ring mail, and [human](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)") [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian") start each game with +0 ring mail.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) [Orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") characters in a role that starts with ring mail receive [orcish ring mail](/wiki/Orcish_ring_mail "Orcish ring mail") instead.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

In addition to random generation, general [stores](/wiki/Store "Store"), used armor dealerships and antique weapon outlets can sell ring mail.

[Mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenaries "Mercenaries") that have not been given body armor have a 8⁄15 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") ring mail that counts for 3 points of their target AC.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

The [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level") "[bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones")" pile has a 1⁄2 chance of containing ring mail with an [enchantment](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") of +0 to +2 that has a 1⁄3 chance of being [erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion")-proofed and a 3⁄4 chance of being cursed.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

## Description

While worn, ring mail grants 3 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and [MC1](/wiki/MC1 "MC1").

## Strategy

[Studded leather armor](/wiki/Studded_leather_armor "Studded leather armor") is generally preferred to ring mail: it is cheaper, weighs 50 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum") less, and does not interfere with [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting") for magic-focused roles. The starting set of ring mail for Barbarians and Knights is passable for the early stages, and will typically be replaced with better armor as soon as it becomes available.

## History

Ring mail first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial list of armor for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on those versions, ring mail does not grant any [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation_\(3.4.3\) "Magic cancellation (3.4.3)").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Ring armour](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_armour "wikipedia:Ring armour")***

Ring armour (or ring mail) is a type of personal armour believed to be constructed as a series of metallic rings sewn or tied directly to a fabric or leather item of clothing such as a jacket or trousers - this would make it more similar to studded leather armor. Unlike [chain mail](/wiki/Chain_mail "Chain mail") and similar armor, ring armour does not have the rings physically interlocked with each other.

Though ring mail is a standard type of armor in the *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* role-playing game, as well as other games and media inspired by it, no historic examples of ring armour are known to exist in European collections or archaeological excavations in Europe. The term "mail" was used in the Victorian era for any form of metallic body armour; "ring mail" as a term does not occur until around the 19th century. Most examples of ring mail are based on speculative interpretations of medieval artwork and historical accounts.

## Variants

In variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions, worn ring mail may not grant any MC.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), ring mail grants 1 base AC and 2 [DR](/wiki/DR "DR") while worn, and its weight is reduced to 125 aum (half of its weight in vanilla *NetHack*).

[Incantifier](/wiki/Incantifier "Incantifier") Barbarians have their ring mail replaced with a [robe](/wiki/Robe "Robe").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)") Barbarians receive a simple [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet") in place of ring mail. [Aligned champions](/wiki/Champion_\(monster\) "Champion (monster)") have a 2⁄3 chance of generating with ring mail.

Ring mail can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield") and a helmet. Ring mail can be used to forge a few items:

- Ring mail can be combined with [scale mail](/wiki/Scale_mail "Scale mail") to create [banded mail](/wiki/Banded_mail "Banded mail").
- Two sets of ring mail can be combined to create chain mail.
- Ring mail can be combined with an [orcish shield](/wiki/Orcish_shield "Orcish shield") to create [orcish chain mail](/wiki/Orcish_chain_mail "Orcish chain mail").
- Ring mail can be combined with a helmet to create scale mail.

### SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, [incantifier](/wiki/Incantifier "Incantifier") Barbarians also have their ring mail replaced with a [robe](/wiki/Robe_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Robe (SLASH'EM)").
